Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Energy for Maine (ME) is a three-year project that will develop, implement and evaluate a model to increase the STEM competencies and career aspirations of students in rural communities. The project will directly engage at least 50 teachers, 100 students and their families to increase STEM energy content knowledge and technology proficiencies by analyzing, discussing, and responding to locally-relevant energy issues through both in- and out-of-school activities. This model will be developed on Maine's islands and coastal communities by networking 17 middle and high schools through interdisciplinary professional development experiences, project-based technology integration in the classroom, and home-based enrichment activities. The goal of the project is to increase students' understanding, motivation, and self-efficacy towards STEM concepts and careers through their participation in innovative technology-infused energy inquiry.

The project will build upon the successful model for teacher professional development that was developed by the CREST program (NSF Awards: 0525118 & 0737588), as it will combine place-based education strategies, nonhierarchal learning environments, and integrated technology to stimulate inquiry-based learning. While deploying innovative new approaches to facilitate inter-generational learning, the project will integrate the analysis of real-time energy data in the classroom to motivate student engagement and meet learning standards through a local context. Students will strengthen their understanding of fundamental concepts in physics (e.g. electricity and transformation of energy) and engineering (e.g. power generation and distribution, home heating and heat transfer) as they learn how these concepts influence the efficient use of energy in their own homes and community buildings.

Project Summary: Energy for ME (E4ME), a three-year strategies project, developed, implemented and evaluated a model to increase STEM competencies and career aspirations of students in rural communities. The project directly engaged about 50 teachers, 200 students and their families, and 10 school facilities managers to decrease energy costs by over $135,000 and avoid more than 900,000 lbs. of carbon emissions. The project increased STEM energy content knowledge and technology proficiencies through student analysis, discussion, and response to locally-relevant energy issues through in- and out-of-school activities. This model was developed on Maine’s islands and coastal communities by networking 10 middle and high schools through interdisciplinary professional development experiences, project-based technology integration in the classroom, and home-based enrichment activities. Energy for ME   increased students’ understanding, motivation, and self-efficacy towards STEM concepts and careers through their participation in innovative, technology-infused energy inquiry.

 

Intellectual Merit: External evaluation concluded that this project met each of its goals.  E4ME developed a model for integrating the collection and analysis of real-time energy data in the classroom to increase student self-efficacy and motivation toward STEM. We were able to combine teacher professional development rooted in place-based, authentic educational experiences infused with technology, and student-driven out-of-school learning that motivated students and their families toward STEM understanding.  We increased students’ critical STEM competencies around the physics, mathematics, and engineering of energy systems and data collection, analysis, and presentation, and increased student interest in and knowledge of their school, home, and community energy issues and options for solutions through data collection, analysis, and presentation (using spreadsheets, GIS, and digital ethnography).  E4ME increased student interest in STEM careers and parents/caregivers encouragement of STEM skill-building and career paths through exposure to career opportunities in the fields of energy efficiency and renewable energy.  We developed an informed and motivated community that partners schools, family units, energy stakeholders, and the larger community to seek active, participatory, and community-minded energy solutions.

The evaluation confirmed the significance of the project’s Summer Institute (SI) professional development model, where selected students and teachers participated in a one-week, campus-based training and activity event.  The SI’s non-hierarchical learning model consistently yielded very favorable results in knowledge gain for both teachers and students. The specially designed curriculum resulted in significant changes in four of the five outcomes: awareness, behavior, career attitudes, and knowledge.  Student engagement in out-of-school E4ME activities often predicted gains above and beyond the classroom level.  E4ME students were significantly better at reading and interpreting graphs compared to students who experienced the project through the classroom only. 

 

Broader Impact: As stated, participating communities saved more than $135,000 in homeowner and school building electricity costs, which equals 900,000 lbs. of carbon or 1,000,000 kWh of energy.
